Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Dissecting ant societies: elucidating how colony size affects brain and behavioral specializations
Award.AbstractNarration: This dissertation research seeks to understand how brain anatomy correlates with task-specialization within ant societies. The research develops a model experimental system of acacia ants, which nest symbiotically in hollow spines of acacia plants, feed on food produced by the plant, and in return protect the plant. Acacia ants are ideal for this study because workers are similar in shape but exhibit distinct behavioral groups that are specialized on different tasks critical for the coordinated functioning of the society. The research specifically tests (1) whether task-specialization correlates with different brain structures; and (2) how society size affects the behavioral and neuro-anatomical specialization among workers. The research contributes to the understanding of animal sociality. The research will be the first to use multiple behavioral groups of an ant species to explore the links between brain and behavior, while controlling for worker morphology. The study will also provide insights into the poorly understood brain anatomy of ants that rely heavily on visual stimuli and visual communication. The investigations involve collaborating researchers in Panama, Costa Rica, and the USA, as well as field sites in Costa Rica and Panama. As part of the research, the doctoral trainee is supervising the Master's thesis of a female student from the Universidad de Costa Rica. Undergraduate students from the University of Texas and a high school student are digitally reconstructing brain anatomy. The trainee also disseminates research results through regular presentations to students, schoolteachers, park rangers, and naturalist guides.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In social animals, group size can affect the behavior and brain anatomy of individuals. The Task-Specialization hypothesis proposes that larger group size enables behavioral specialization among group members, which corresponds to anatomical specialization of brains. The Social Brain hypothesis proposes that increased levels of social stimuli in larger colonies lead to enlarged brain regions in all members, regardless of task specialization. We tested these hypotheses in acacia ants on the dry forests of Panama and Costa Rica. In a colony of acacia ants, workers can specialize in either collecting food or in defending the tree where they nest or the colony.

We mainly found support for the task-specialization hypothesis, as we documented that the volume of certain brain regions used in learning and memory change with group size depending on the specialization of the ants.Brain anatomy results suggest that group size could affect cognitive abilities of group members. Specifically, we found that ants specialized on defense living in larger colonies have relatively smaller brain regions than ants also working on defense but living in a smaller colony.

Our study involved researchers from the University of Arizona, the Smithsonian Tropical Research Institute at Panama, three undergraduate students from Panama and Costa Rica, and eight undergraduate students from the University of Texas at Austin. During the field season, undergraduate students were trained in collecting and analyzing behavioral data at the facilities of the STRI, an undergraduate student from Costa Rica was trained in laboratory techniques for dissecting, staining and imaging insect brains, and students from the University of Texas at Austin where trained in digital 3D reconstructions of the brain. Also, through this project we developed workshops with the participation of more than 100 primary school science teachers at Panama, and worked with park rangers.
